dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we've been, uh, talking a lot about the pandemic, obviously, but there's another kind of war being waged right now, and it's against, like, scammers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we've been, uh, talking a lot about the pandemic, obviously, but there's another kind of war being waged right now, and it's against, like, scammers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Across the world, law enforcement and intelligence agencies are waging a different kind of war on COVID-19, one taking on scammers whore exploiting fear around the coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, you mean the ones exploiting fear, selling fake cures, or, um, trying to get people to donate to bogus charities?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, you mean the ones exploiting fear, selling fake cures, or, um, trying to get people to donate to bogus charities?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And in the UK, especially, the GCHQ intelligence agency, through their National Cyber Security Centre – NCSC – they've been really going after these COVID-19 crooks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And in the U K, especially, the G C H Q intelligence agency, through their National Cyber Security Centre - N C S C - they've been really going after these C O V I D-nineteen crooks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the U.K., an arm of the GCHQ intelligence agency, has spent the last month wiping COVID-19 crooks from the web, with the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) announcing Monday that it had taken down more than 2,000 scams in a single month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, I mean, it feels like there's so many out there. How many have they actually, uh, managed to take down?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, I mean, it feels like there's so many out there. How many have they actually, uh, managed to take down?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Over 2,000 scams in just one month! It's wild. Everything from, uh, fake online stores selling non-existent items to websites trying to infect your computer with malware.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Over two thousand scams in just one month! It's wild. Everything from, uh, fake online stores selling non-existent items to websites trying to infect your computer with malware.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) announcing Monday that it had taken down more than 2,000 scams in a single month. The swindles included: 471 stores selling fraudulent coronavirus related items, 555 websites trying to launch malware on visitors...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Malware? [overlapping] That's just so awful. And, like, phishing sites, I assume, trying to snag your personal info?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Malware? That's just so awful. And, like, phishing sites, I assume, trying to snag your personal info?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, definitely phishing for passwords, credit card details. And those, like, advance-fee frauds where they trick you into paying a small setup fee for a huge return that never materializes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, definitely phishing for passwords, credit card details. And those, like, advance-fee frauds where they trick you into paying a small setup fee for a huge return that never materializes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...200 phishing sites seeking personal information such as passwords or credit card details, and 832 advance-fee frauds where victims are duped into handing over a set-up payment in the belief theyll get a large sum in return.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's truly despicable, you know? The UK security minister James Brokenshire, he, um, called it out, said they're using the outbreak as cover.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's truly despicable, you know? The U K security minister James Brokenshire, he, um, called it out, said they're using the outbreak as cover.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its despicable that they are using the coronavirus outbreak as cover to try to scam and steal from people in their homes. said the U.K. minister for security James Brokenshire.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: He's right. But the good news is, we can actually help! GCHQ and City of London police launched a Suspicious Email Reporting Service.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He's right. But the good news is, we can actually help! G C H Q and City of London police launched a Suspicious Email Reporting Service.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the GCHQ organization has collaborated with the City of London police to launch the Suspicious Email Reporting Service.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's great! My inbox has been, like, a minefield lately. So, beyond reporting, what else can we, uh, do to protect ourselves?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's great! My inbox has been, like, a minefield lately. So, beyond reporting, what else can we, uh, do to protect ourselves?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the NCSC also has this "Cyber Aware" guide. Simple stuff like, you know, turning on two-factor authentication, using three random words for passwords, and, um, keeping your software updated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the N C S C also has this Cyber Aware guide. Simple stuff like, you know, turning on two-factor authentication, using three random words for passwords, and, um, keeping your software updated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Cyber Aware advice includes some rudimentary, simple and effective things people can do to be more secure at home, including: Turn on two-factor authentication for important accounts Protect important accounts using a password of three random words Update the software and apps on your devices regularly (ideally set to automatically update)

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, updating is key. And always, like, backing up your important data, right? Just in case.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, updating is key. And always, like, backing up your important data, right? Just in case.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To protect yourself from being held to ransom, back up important data

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And on a bigger scale, the NCSC and the U.S. even teamed up to issue a massive alert, listing, like, 2,500 dodgy sites and emails to watch out for.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And on a bigger scale, the N C S C and the U.S. even teamed up to issue a massive alert, listing, like, two thousand, five hundred dodgy sites and emails to watch out for.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier this month, the NCSC and the U.S. joined forces to issue an alert about COVID-19 scams, releasing a growing list of 2,500 websites and emails to watch out for.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] That's a huge effort! But, hey, any, like, positive news amidst all this craziness?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a huge effort! But, hey, any, like, positive news amidst all this craziness?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Actually, yeah! Even though cryptocurrency scammers are trying to cash in on the pandemic, their profits have surprisingly dropped by 33% in dollar terms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Actually, yeah! Even though cryptocurrency scammers are trying to cash in on the pandemic, their profits have surprisingly dropped by thirty three percent in dollar terms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But in better news, though cryptocurrency scammers are taking advantage of the worlds focus on the coronavirus, their profits have actually dropped 33% in dollar terms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's, like, genuinely fantastic news. So, the good guys *are* making a dent, then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's, like, genuinely fantastic news. So, the good guys are making a dent, then.
